sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for Kāf

revisionDesc.change: Changed Status to done, apart from a few entries on draft the document is ready to be validated.
Removed the k_lex value because it applied to only one dialect and replaced in by two FVOs
Removed the k_g value because it applied to only one dialect and it is an assimilation case already contemplated in the chapter

item.label: k + affrication (in the environment of anterior vowel) /ć/
k + affrication (in the environment of anterior vowel) /č/

div.head: Reflexes of *k
General remarks
div.p: The map for this feature shows the value that is generally used in the specific location according to the sources. More common exceptions concerning the realization of /k/ are discussed in this paragraph (and in the notes of every feature value observation)yet not represented as different values in the map.

Particularly regarding affricated reflexes, there are generational differences in many regions where this feature is common. The common tendency is towards de-affrication (č > k) among the younger generation under the influence of Standard Arabic and regional prestige varieties. In case we have reliable socio-linguistic information, such generational differences are also indicated on the map.
Loanwords from MSA or Classical Arabic are often not affected by affrication, e.g. words like kitāb ‘book’ are usually pronounced with [k] and not with [ʧ]

In many varieties where non-affricated and affricated dialects have got into mutual contact, the distribution of /k/ and /č/ is more or less lexicalized and does no longer follow the phonological rules given below. E.g., Baghdad: ḏaki ‘intelligent’ (and not *ḏači), fikra ‘idea’ (and not *fičra).
The peculiar shift *k > š, which is restricted to the 2sg.f pronominal suffix -iš/-š in some dialects of southern and eastern Arabia, has not been considered.
The values in the map do not represent punctual changes in the realization of /k/ that are due to assimilation processes in certain lexemes or roots, e.g. *kbīr > gbīr ‘big’.

In several dialects of northern Syria, Mesopotamia, and Arabia, the phoneme /č/ occurs also in loanwords from Turkish, Persian and English. Such words are not considered, because in these cases the sound [ʧ] cannot be regarded as a reflex of OA *k.

When values /k/ [k] + affricate č [ʧ] and /k/ [k] + affricate ć [ʦ] are indicated, affrication is only realized in the environment of an anterior vowel. In the rest of environments, the phoneme is realized as /k/ [k]. In the few cases where affrication or the lack thereof is lexicalized, the two values /k/ [k] and /č/ [ʧ] are indicated along with an explicative note.

div.head: Geographical distribution
div.p: The “standard” and “classical” pronunciation of /k/ as a voiceless velar stop [k] is still very widespread in the east and it is by far the most common reflex in all Arabic varieties spoken in North Africa.
The palatalized reflex , which can be seen as the first step towards affrication, is rather rare and more or less restricted to south-eastern Arabia and scattered occurrences in Algeria.

Many eastern Bedouin-type dialects show affrication of /k/ in specific phonetic environments. It is assumed that the dialects at the periphery of Arabia exhibit the older stage affrication *k > č [ʧ], whereas the central dialects of the camel breeding nomadic tribes surface a further stage of affrication, which is *k > *č > ć [ʦ].

The unconditioned affrication of *k to č [ʧ] is attested for several non-connected regions situated far apart from each other: a small pocket of dialects in northern Yemen and south-western Saudi Arabia, some Omani dialects, and the dialects of Central Palestine. There is an ongoing discussion whether or not this sound shift is a contact-induced feature that has been triggered through contact with Bedouins; see e.g. (Behnstedt 2016: 21 with further references).
Affricated *k > *č > ć [ʦ] in Jewish dialects of Morocco?

div.head: Discussion / Theoretical Remarks
div.p: REFLEXES OF k IN THE BEDOUIN-SEDENTARY SPLIT – a bit of a lit review, highlight the significance of this feature and why we consider this feature needs to be part of the database.

wib:featureValueObservation.note: The younger speakers seem to have lost affrication in some lexical items, in contrast with middle age and old speakers. Ex. smika
Middle-age speakers use affrication of k to č very rarely in natural speech but report to use it when speaking to the older generation

Affrication of k to č is normally identified as one of the most salient features marking the "Bedouin" character of this community's variety. This feature is subject of mockery from the young generation

Inhabitants of this population are 75% autochtonous Muslim and 25% are Bedouins from the Nǧēdāt. Data collected from 5 participants of different ages but not specified that the speakers are of Bedouin origin
Extinct feature
Apart for a very occassional š when followed by a plosive, as in štūf (shoulders)
k before e/i may be preserved when labialised. ex. turkwiyya

Exceptions are: čān - yikūn; ʾabū-k «ton père (m.)» et ʾabū-č «ton père (f.); [k] is reestablished in the passive participles of verbs C-C-k of scheme *maC1C2ūC3 (ex. manyūk, maʿlūk and mahlūk)
There is desaffrication when in contact with coronal consonants d, t, ḏ, ṯ and ̣ḏ
čān - yikūn

It is a recessive feature ("Le caractère récessif de /č/ est indéniable puisque on ne le trouve plus que chez les locuteurs âgés et peu instruits, ce qui avait déjà été remarqué au début du 20ème siècle par Bergsträsser").
exceptions: dyūč „chickens‟, člūb (family name)

Wuhūb Siḥmān + Fruda (Northern Central) and Bedouin of mountains, especially Banu Masrūḥ (including ʕAwf, Ṣawāʕid, Laqāmīn) + Ṣubḥ of Banu Sālim, Banu Ayūb in al-Xiraiba and ʕIbida of Banu ʕAmr have ḱ
no ex.
no ex.
Only in text A of the publication (which presents a Bedouinized tendency), in texts B and C no
the variants are phonetically conditioned: k occurrs in the contiguity of back vowels, and č of front vowels
no ex.

feature value taken from the table inventory of consonants
vestigial variants: čīl "measure, weight", yčammilen "they (f.) complete", čänna "daughter in law", etc.

Affrication in the vicinity of front vowel /č/ shows a regressive character within this dialect. It rarely appears in spontaneous speech, and when occurring it is only used by the oldest speakers. These instances can be defined vestigial variants.
Ex taken from text, no ex in the corpus of article
Pronounced g when in contact position before the voiced bilabial plosive b
especially in the environment of front vowels
It might be that the affrication is blocked by the vicinity of back vowels but sometimes the same word is sometimtes affricated and sometimes not (even by the same speakers)
It might be that the affrication is blocked by the vicinity of back vowels but sometimes the same word is sometimtes affricated and sometimes not (even by the same speakers)
In certain MSA loandwords the k is preserverd like in malik "king" and k is preserved in the second person singular masculine pronominal suffix

young, educated don't affriciate, one clan affricates everything

2nd person masc. Sg. possessive suffix stays -(a)k, haḏ̣āk "that" (pron. masc.), haḏīk "that" (pron. fem.), haḏolāk "those" (pron. pl.), hanāk "there", hēḏḏāk; words with the root ktb "writing", words with the root kwn "being" are sometimes affricated, sometimes not, phrases like as-salāmu ʿalaykum "peace be upon you", new loandwords are sometimes affricated, sometimes not

The x̣ describes the "post-palatal", i. e. velar, fricative, quoted as a mixture between the two fricatives š and ḫ. It corresponds to the x of the IPA.
The pronominal suffix of the second person singular feminine may be an affricate č (as noted in Poésies Fezzanaises).
/k/ occasionally appears as /g/, e.g. gdəb `lie`
Affrication in fronting environments only.
It occasionally occurs in back-vowel environments, e.g. smūč (fishes).
The sound ć also appears instead of other phonemes, e.g. ćāy ("tea").
This realisation occurs in frontal positions only.
There may be overlap between the voiceless fricative and plosive velars (x ~ k).
This realisation occurs when the k is in final position only.
Not to be confused, in this case, not the k but the t is affricated.
The exact realization is [ʨ].
In some loanwords k becomes ḳ (Cohen 1975: 32)
often labialisation takʷli "you eat" (f)
allophone ç after interdentals, and in intervocalis and postvocalic positions, e.g. bĭntəç 'your daughter'
deduced from example text
allophone /k'/ before front and non-front vowels
/k/ sometimes is reflected as /g/ e.g. gideb 'he lied'
k is treated like a sun letter: rrmād dəkkānūn "the ashes of the fire"
Jewish dialcts in Tafilalt: k > t l-tlb "the dog"
When in contact with a voiceless consonant, the /k/ is often reflected as a /g/
lexicalized labialisation kʷbar "big"
sometimes pharyngalized
allophone: can occur as an emphatic sometimes,
